resources.string:
Welcome to KanaSRS!
Once this app has been completed, you will be able to read the kana above 「ようこそ」 and much, much more!

While reading is about recognizing, writing the kana is about recalling the image of it in your mind. This can create a deeper connection during the learning process, and is very beneficial! However, we understand if your goal is not aligned with the need to write. So, we have created the option to turn off all writing related stats and functions. You will be able to turn it back on at any time, and turning it off and on will not reset progress.

This setting can be used to randomly assign a new font on every review item. Reading computer font compared to handwriting can be vastly different, as in most languages. There are many styles, so we provide the option to review with variety.
Hiragana is one of the three character sets, and is one of two phonetic lettering systems.
Phonetic means the characters have no special meaning, but rather make up the basic sounds.
You will learn the basic 46 letters, with some additional modifications that make up the rest of the sounds.
Hiragana is typically used for grammatical patterns, as well as some words.
Katakana is the second character set, and like hiragana, is also phonetic.
The syllables included in hiragana and katakana are the same, however katakana has different usages.
The most common is that katakana is used for foreign loan words. You will notice Japanese people use a lot of english sounding words, because they do! This includes a lot of scientific words as well.
Katakana also looks really cool, sharp, and modern! Many companies may use katakana for their name, logo, or signs!
Kanji is the final character set, and also the biggest! Unlike hiragana and katakana, these characters are not phonetic!
Each character has its own meaning, and corresponds to a word and idea. They can be used on their own, or put together to create different words.

Kanji originates from China, but has long since been imported into Japanese. Hiragana and katakana are much quicker to learn since kanji has thousands of characters to learn, but don\'t be overwhelmed!
This app does not teach kanji, but will work through the kana systems. Bit by bit, the Japanese alphabet will be covered! Remember, it\'s not a marathon! Take your time.
